Issues.Title: fix(ivy): take styles extracted from template into account in JIT mode
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, all styles extracted from Component's template (defined using <style> tags) were ignored by JIT compiler, so only `styles` array values defined in @Component decorator were used. This change updates JIT compiler to take styles extracted from the template into account. It also ensures correct order where `styles` array values are applied first and template styles are applied second.

This PR resolves FW-1744.

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): take styles extracted from template into account in JIT mode" (#34017)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): recompile on template change in ngc watch mode on Windows
Issues.Body:
In #33551, a bug in `ngc --watch` mode was fixed so that a component is
recompiled when its template file is changed. Due to insufficient
normalization of files paths, this fix did not have the desired effect
on Windows.

Fixes #32869

Issues.Title: Allow non-ASCII characters in Template Expressions
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request ### Relevant Package This feature request is for @angular/compiler ### Description Allowing any characters which are valid in ECMAScript specification. #### Problem Currently, Angular's template parser doesn't allow non-ASCII characters in an expression part. For example, `ÊàëÁöÑ` consists of chinese characters as below; ```ts @Component({ selector: 'my-app', template: '
{{ ÊàëÁöÑ }}
', }) export class AppComponent { // Chinese character ÊàëÁöÑ = 'Angular'; } ``` It throws template parsing error like the below; ``` Template parse errors: Parser Error: Unexpected token Lexer Error: Unexpected character [Êàë] at column 2 in expression [ ÊàëÁöÑ ] at column 3 in [{{ ÊàëÁöÑ }}] in ng:///AppModule/AppComponent.html@0:5 ("
[ERROR ->]{{ ÊàëÁöÑ }}
"): ng:///AppModule/AppComponent.html@0:5 ``` https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-nu81kk?file=src/app/app.component.ts #### Causes This is a problem at the scanning phase of the lexer. https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/8c76e78ec454b0b9c2d1fadb6c3d1d1202772ea5/packages/compiler/src/expression_parser/lexer.ts#L160 This line tries to judge that the character is the start of an _idenfiter_. In the above context, an identifier is `ÊàëÁöÑ`. But the scanner's `isIdentifierStart` method allows only characters like ASCII. https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/8c76e78ec454b0b9c2d1fadb6c3d1d1202772ea5/packages/compiler/src/expression_parser/lexer.ts#L334-L337 As a result, `Êàë` is not recognized the start of the identifier and at last, the scanner throws an unexpected token error. #### Usecase In the JavaScript context, `this.ÊàëÁöÑ` is valid. Sometime non-English developers prefer using their own language in the code for readability. ### Describe the solution you'd like To solve this, Angular has to change the code around finding identifiers. For only expression scope, I guess it is not too difficult. ### Related issues https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/517 This is a very old issue. Some issues have been closed due to duplication to that, but we may need to reset the discussion about this problem. cc/ @zackarychapple
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow non-ASCII characters in Template Expressions" (#34003)

Issues.Title: refactor(ivy): Add style reconciliation algorithm
Issues.Body:
# refactor(core): Add array modification functions.
This change introduces several functions for manipulating items in an array in an efficient (binary search) way.

- `arraySplice` a faster version of `Array.splice()`.
- `arrayInsert` a faster version of `Array.splice(index, 0, value)`.
- `arrayInsertSorted` a way to insert a value into sorted list.
- `arrayRemoveSorted` a way to remove a value from a sorted list.
- `arrayIndexOfSorted` a way to find a value in a sorted list.

# refactor(ivy): Add style reconciliation algorithm

This change introduces class/style reconciliation algorithm for DOM elements.
NOTE: The code is not yet hooked up, it will be used by future style algorithm.

Background: 
Styling algorithm currently has [two paths](https://hackmd.io/@5zDGNGArSxiHhgvxRGrg-g/rycZk3N5S) when computing how the style should be rendered. 
1. A direct path which concatenates styling and uses `elemnent.className`/`element.style.cssText` and
2. A merge path which uses internal data structures and uses `element.classList.add/remove`/`element.style[property]`.

The situation is confusing and hard to follow/maintain. So a future PR will remove the merge-path and do everything with direct-path. This however breaks when some other code adds class or style to the element without Angular's knowledge. If this happens instead of switching from direct-path to merge-path algorithm, this change provides a different mental model whereby we always do `direct-path` but the code which writes to the DOM detects the situation and reconciles the out of bound write.

The reconciliation process is as follows:
1. Detect that no one has modified `className`/`cssText` and if so just write directly (fast path).
2. If out of bounds write did occur, switch from writing using `className`/`cssText` to `element.classList.add/remove`/`element.style[property]`. This does require that the write function computes the difference between the previous Angular expected state and current Angular state. (This requires a parser. The advantage of having a parser is that we can support `style="width: {{exp}}px"` kind of bindings.) Compute the diff and apply it in non destructive way using `element.classList.add/remove`/`element.style[property]`

Properties of approach:
- If no out of bounds style modification:
  - Very fast code path: Just concatenate string in right order and write them to DOM.
  - Class list order is preserved
- If out of bounds style modification detected:
  - Penalty for parsing 
  - Switch to non destructive modification: `element.classList.add/remove`/`element.style[property]`
  - Switch to alphabetical way of setting classes.

    at drainMicroTaskQueue (zone-evergreen.js:559)`

What on earth am I doing wrong? Every tutorial, training site and example does it this way, but I cannot find any information on this specific error message. Please help.

Issues.Title: Make ZoneAwarePromise spec compliant and compatible with core-js
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/zone.js

### Description
I'm not an Angular developer so I'm not in much of a position to provide details on the Angular side. I'm a developer working on a webpack application that uses core-js to provide polyfills and my application is one that other sites can embed in their application.

The core-js polyfill does some checks to determine if the system has a spec compliant Promise and if not, it will use its own setting it in the global scope. The ZoneAwarePromise does not pass the core-js checks and as a result gets overridden by core-js with the result being that the Angular application stops functioning.

Most of the initial responses to this problem is that you should load the core-js application first but in our case that is not an option since we're an external application that is loaded later as an asynchronous embedding.

There was an issue file for exactly this in the zone.js repo: https://github.com/angular/zone.js/issues/783 so I'm basically recreating that issue here. That issue was just closed without any actual resolution and then the whole repo was archived when it was merged here.

There was a similar question posed in core-js: https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/issues/319 that offers a suggestion for what seems like a simple change that can be made to ZoneAwarePromise that would make it compliant enough to pass the core-js checks.

The project that we were causing trouble for was using Angular 7.2.15.

### Describe the solution you'd like
https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/issues/319#issuecomment-317036136

### Describe alternatives you've considered
In our webpack application, the solution was to not import the polyfill as part of the webpack configuration but to only do it conditionally if there is no Promise at all:

```
if (!window.Promise) {
  require('core-js/modules/es.promise');
}
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Make ZoneAwarePromise spec compliant and compatible with core-js" (#33989)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fix budget checks
Issues.Body:
Fixes #15792.

This turned out to be a little more complicated than expected due to the combination of a few different problems resulting in broken budget checks.

* File sizes were previously computed in a Webpack plugin, which is executed during certain lifecycle hooks. I needed to move this to run *after* the build when all the necessary file size information is known. The first commit refactors the size computations without any significant changes to the output.
* Files listed as `lazy: true` or `inject: false` in the app dev's `angular.json` file were included in the `initial` bundle, even though these resources must be loaded asynchronously. The second commit filters out files which were marked asynchronous from the `initial` bundle.
* Differential builds were included in the same size, so the `main` size was including both the ES2015 **and** ES5 sizes together, which isn't what the user would want. The third commit updates the relevant budgets to output two sizes, one for each differential build, rather than including them together.

I made separate commits performing each of these steps individually to make the logic a little easier to follow and understand.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fix budget checks" (#16268)

Issues.Title: build: update @bazel/bazel to version 1.2.0
Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [@bazel/bazel](https://bazel.build/) ([source](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs)) | devDependencies | minor | [`1.1.0` -> `1.2.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/@bazel%2fbazel/1.1.0/1.2.0) |
| [@bazel/jasmine](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs) | devDependencies | minor | [`0.40.0` -> `0.41.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/@bazel%2fjasmine/0.40.0/0.41.0) |
| [@bazel/karma](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs) | devDependencies | minor | [`0.40.0` -> `0.41.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/@bazel%2fkarma/0.40.0/0.41.0) |
| [@bazel/labs](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs) | devDependencies | minor | [`0.40.0` -> `0.41.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/@bazel%2flabs/0.40.0/0.41.0) |
| [@bazel/typescript](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs) | devDependencies | minor | [`0.40.0` -> `0.41.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/@bazel%2ftypescript/0.40.0/0.41.0) |
| [bazel_toolchains](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/bazel-toolchains) | http_archive | patch | [`1.1.2` -> `1.1.3`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/bazelbuild%2fbazel-toolchains/1.1.2/1.1.3) |
| [build_bazel_rules_nodejs](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs) | http_archive | minor | [`0.40.0` -> `0.41.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/bazelbuild%2frules_nodejs/0.40.0/0.41.0) |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bazelbuild/rules_nodejs</summary>

### [`v0.41.0`](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​0410httpsgithubcombazelbuildrulesnodejscompare04000410-2019-11-22)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/compare/0.40.0...0.41.0)

To upgrade:

    http_archive(
        name = "build_bazel_rules_nodejs",
        sha256 = "8dc1466f8563f3aa4ac7ab7aa3c96651eb7764108219f40b2d1c918e1a81c601",
        urls = ["https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/releases/download/0.41.0/rules_nodejs-0.41.0.tar.gz"],
    )

and run `yarn upgrade --scope @​bazel` to update all your `@bazel`-scoped npm packages to the latest versions.
(or manually do the npm equivalent - they don't have a way to update a scope)

##### BREAKING CHANGES

As mentioned before, we are close to a 1.0 release, so we are making all our breaking changes now to prepare for a period of stability. Sorry for the long list this time!

-   `web_package` rule has been renamed to `pkg_web` and is now a public API

Update your load statements from

```python
load("@​build_bazel_rules_nodejs//internal/web_package:web_package.bzl", "web_package")
```

to

```python
load("@​build_bazel_rules_nodejs//:index.bzl", "pkg_web")
```

-   `ts_devserver` and `pkg_web` (previously `web_package`) no longer have an `index_html` attribute.

They expect an index.html file to be among the assets, and to already
have the script and link tags needed for the app to work.

The feature where those tags were injected into the html dynamically has
been moved to its own rule, inject_html.

We are in a transition state where the `inject_html` rule is not published, because we want this to be a plain npm package and not Bazel-specific. We will publish this functionality soon. If you depend on it, you may want to delay this upgrade.

-   internal/rollup_bundle rule is removed. see <https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/wiki> for migration instructions

-   Removed the expand_location_into_runfiles helper from //internal:node.bzl
    Load it from //internal/common:expand_into_runfiles instead

-   npm karma deps for karma_web_test and karma_web_suite are now peer deps so that the versions used can be chosen by the user.

This PR also removes the built-in  `@io_bazel_rules_webtesting//browsers/sauce:chrome-win10` saucelabs support. It is not very useful as it only tests a single browser and it difficult to use. In the angular repo, saucelabs support was implemented with a custom karma config using karma_web_test. This is the recommended approach.

-   `--define=DEBUG=1` is no longer functional to request debugging outputs. Use `-c dbg` instead (this matches Bazel's behavior for C++).

-   We renamed some of the generated targets in the `@nodejs//` workspace:

`bazel run @​nodejs//:npm` is replaced with `bazel run @​nodejs//:npm_node_repositories` and `bazel run @​nodejs//:yarn` is replaced with `bazel run @​nodejs//:yarn_node_repositories`. `@nodejs//:yarn` and `@nodejs//:npm` now run yarn & npm in the current working directory instead of on all of the `package.json` files in `node_repositories()`.

`@nodejs//:bin/node` & `@nodejs//:bin/node.cmd` (on Windows) are no longer valid targets. Use `@nodejs//:node` instead on all platforms. You can still call the old targets in their platform specific node repositories such as `@nodejs_darwin_amd64//:bin/node`.

`@nodejs//:bin/yarn` & `@nodejs//:bin/yarn.cmd` (on Windows) are no longer valid targets. Use `@nodejs//:yarn` instead on all platforms. You can still call the old targets in their platform specific node repositories such as `@nodejs_darwin_amd64//:bin/yarn`.

`@nodejs//:bin/npm` & `@nodejs//:bin/npm.cmd` (on Windows) are no longer valid targets. Use `@nodejs//:npm` instead on all platforms. You can still call the old targets in their platform specific node repositories such as `@nodejs_darwin_amd64//:bin/npm`.

##### Bug Fixes

-   **builtin:** allow .tsx entry_point in node binary/test ([313d484](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/313d484)), closes [#​1351](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/issues/1351)
-   **terser:** call terser binary instead of uglifyjs ([#​1360](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/issues/1360)) ([a100420](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/a100420))
-   **terser:** remove ngDevMode & ngI18nClosureMode global_defs from default terser config ([98c8dbc](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/98c8dbc))

##### chore

-   remove deprecated re-export file ([148bf8a](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/148bf8a))
-   remove old rollup_bundle ([9a824ac](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/9a824ac)), closes [#​740](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/issues/740)

##### Code Refactoring

-   move injector feature to own rule ([be06d23](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/be06d23))

##### Features

-   node-patches\\filesystem patcher. ([#​1332](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/issues/1332)) ([0b2f675](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/0b2f675))
-   support --compilation_mode flag ([9fa4343](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/9fa4343))
-   **builtin:** rename @​nodejs//:npm and @​nodejs//:yarn to @​nodejs//:[yarn/npm]\_node_repositories ([#​1369](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/issues/1369)) ([01079a3](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/01079a3))
-   **karma:** npm peer deps & remove [@​rules](https://togithub.com/rules)\_webtesting//browsers/sauce:chrome-win10 support ([318bbf3](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/318bbf3))
-   **protractor:** protractor npm package is now a peer deps ([#​1352](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/issues/1352)) ([5db7c8e](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/commit/5db7c8e))

</details>

<details>
<summary>bazelbuild/bazel-toolchains</summary>

### [`v1.1.3`](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/bazel-toolchains/releases/1.1.3)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/bazel-toolchains/compare/1.1.2...1.1.3)

Issues.Title: SCSS source maps no longer work in Safari
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ x ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, until recently scss sourcemaps worked in Safari 13.03 and Technology Preview 13.1 ### Description Run application with `ng serve`, `localhost:8083` Inspect an element on the page in Safari. All the style rules point to the `styles.css` file instead of to their respective SCSS files. Same page viewed in Firefox, Chrome, or Edge correctly displays the scss file to each rule as expected. Checked both versions of Safari on sites that use other methods of compiling SCSS and the maps on those sites work. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. start new app, `ng new` 2. run app, `npm start` 3. add something to the styles.scss file, I added ``` .card { background-color: yellow !important; } ``` 4. reload. cards are yellow. inspect one. 5. style path is "localhost", not "styles.scss" 6. create a partial scss file, "_partial.scss" with the above code in it and import this into an emptied "styles.scss" 7. Cards still yellow, inspector says "localhost" should say "_partial.scss" ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 8.3.19
Node: 10.16.0
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 8.2.14
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... platform-server, router

**Anything else relevant?** As mentioned above, issue is only in Safari browsers 13.03 and 13.1 Inspecting in Safari 13.03: ![CleanShot 2019-11-21 at 14 51 50](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/835148/69371959-d3594400-0c6e-11ea-865b-e31dede205c9.png) Same in Firefox 71: ![CleanShot 2019-11-21 at 14 52 03](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/835148/69371986-deac6f80-0c6e-11ea-8a18-7c890816cc9a.png)

Issues.Title: Generate output bundle in production with "UTF-8 with BOM" encoding
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [x] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "0.800.6". "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "0.800.6" was generating the special symbol in [o.√â¬µp,r.ElementRef,r.Renderer2,r.PLATFORM_ID] excaped in unicode. ### Description In our final bundle main.js generated in Production mode contains the following symbols "√â¬µp" example: [o.√â¬µp,r.ElementRef,r.Renderer2,r.PLATFORM_ID]. Then when we serve it with apache tomcat v.8.5.47 or apache tomcat v.9.0.27 the browser thows a console error which is "Uncaught SyntaxError: Invalid or unexpected token" on Windows machines ### Way to workaround it re-save the the output bundle file (main.js) in UTF-8 with BOM ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1) "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "~0.803.18" in package.json 2) build in production mode 3) serve the app in apache tomcat v.8.5.47 or apache tomcat v.9.0.27 on Windows machines ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Support for CLI extension
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ x] build
- [x ] serve
- [x ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ x] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description

Maybe somebody already asked this but are there any plans in terms of extensibility of CLI build tasks? 


1. I understand right now the recomended way to extend cli is to write schematics to create some custom generate command. Or even override existing ones like some of the cli are doing it.
2. You are also able to use `builder API` to really change behavior or create new for the existing commands (build, serve, test,..)
3. if I want to extends existing build process, then I can extends `browser build` `export default createBuilder` where I can call existinb fn `buildWebpackBrowser as executeBrowserBuilder`, and then do some my own logic

- But what I am strugling with or I dont see a solution, how do I easily extend and alter building process of existing application that might already be using some builder API. 

Current solution does not scale, as you can extend `builder API` and replace application's configuration for your builder, but this would not work if they are already using some custom builder API. So replace is not really an option. 

What you need some Injection points, to be able to register your tasks before, after each task. I know ngx-build-plus is trying to do something similar, but again if we use ngx-build-plus and project has already some builder it will not work. 

Like Maven, Gradle,....

Any pointers ?






### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?

Issues.Title: Update README link for Ripple feature
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Documentation Fix/Bug

#### What is the expected behavior?
When clicking the **Docs** link in the README for the Ripple feature, I should be taken to the material.angular.io page (similar to the links for all other Angular Component features)

#### What is the current behavior?
Links to `.md` file in source control

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
1. Visit the [README.md](https://github.com/angular/components)
2. Click on the **Docs** link for the Ripple feature
3. Note that you're taken to https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/core/ripple/ripple.md

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
The motivation for this change is consistent documentation

Issues.Title: Checkbox: UI bug when implementing "select all" functionality
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
This is simply a fork of the example for adding checkboxes to a table from the docs. The only thing I changed was I added the ELEMENT_DATA as the initial selected value to simulate the case in which all rows start out as checked.

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-vxmvu6?file=src/app/table-selection-example.ts
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

I should be able to select/deselect rows


#### Actual Behavior
The "select all" checkbox displays a bug for a split second. To replicate the bug simply deselect any of the rows but look at the "select all" checkbox, it'll turn to unchecked instead of indeterminate for a brief second, then it will correctly settle on indeterminate. 

I've noticed this bug only occurs the first time, and it'll also not occur if your first action is to toggle "select all" instead of any of the rows. 

I am also positive the bug is not from the cdk as I had initially implemented this without the the cdk collection helper, and that's when I came across the error.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Checkbox: UI bug when implementing "select all" functionality" (#17794)

Issues.Title: build: migrate to new --define=angular_ivy_enabled flag
Issues.Body:
Remove all usage of --define=compile=* within the repo, using --config=ivy and
--config=view-engine instead.  This matches the changes in the angular/angular
repo and is clearer to developers what the flag is actually doing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: migrate to new --define=angular_ivy_enabled flag" (#17792)

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/overlay): fix wrong overflow calculation
Issues.Body:
`overflowBottom` is currently calculated with `viewport.bottom` (which could be any number from the height of the viewport to as large as your page is)
calculating the overflow should just be difference between `overlay.height + start.y` and the height of the viewport, not the height of the entire page.

Right now the overlay is pushed out of the view in certain cases.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(cdk/overlay): fix wrong overflow calculation" (#17791)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "chore(ivy): fix host listener inheritence for mdc-chips and mdc-anchor" (#17790)

Issues.Title: refactor: remove QueryList workaround for type checking
Issues.Body: In earlier 9.0 RCs `QueryList` wasn't inferred as iterable and we were getting compiler errors. The way we worked around it was to convert it into an array. Now that the compiler handles `QueryList` correctly we don't need the workarounds anymore.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: remove QueryList workaround for type checking" (#17789)

Issues.Title: fix(schematics): do not depend on external dependency for colors
Issues.Body:
Currently we assume that `chalk` always is installed. This has worked
without any issues for a long time because most CLI projects had chalk
installed. This could potentially change in the projects, or the verison of
chalk could accidentally be older/more recent than what our schematics
expect. We just remove colors and depend on the devkit logger for colors
based on specific logging levels.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(schematics): do not depend on external dependency for colors" (#17788)

Issues.Title: fix(select): don't handle open key presses while the user is typing
Issues.Body:
We support typing into a select to skip to an item, as well as pressing space to open the select, however if the user is typing something that has a space in it, the select will open and interrupt the user. These changes add some logic so that we don't trigger the panel while the user is typing.

Fixes #17774.

Issues.Title: build: enable bazel node modules symlinking [resubmit w/ fixes]
Issues.Body:
Resubmit with fixes for the release building failures.

The symlinking allowed us use caching for node_modules. This meant that we needed
to rework how we apply postinstall patches to:

*  Still throw if something no longer applies (i.e. when updating Angular)
* To not throw if yarn runs on node_modules  already patched/restored from cache.

To do this, we implemented something called "marker files" that can be used to
determine if a file has been patched or not. Unfortunately I didn't realize that we
have multiple individual patches for the same file, so the first patch edit created the
marker, and followed patches for the same file got skipped.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: enable bazel node modules symlinking [resubmit w/ fixes]" (#17776)

Issues.Title: build: enforce that the descendants flag is set on all queries
Issues.Body: Updates the linting config to require that the `descendants` flag is set on all `ContentChildren` queries so that we can avoid backsliding.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: enforce that the descendants flag is set on all queries" (#17778)

Issues.Title: fix(drag-drop): position reset if viewport is resized while boundary is invisible
Issues.Body:
If a dragged item is inside a boundary, we update its position on window resize to ensure that it stays inside the boundary. If a resize event happens while the boundary is hidden, we end up resetting the user's position unintentionally. These changes add a check that prevents the position from changing if the elements are hidden.

Fixes #17750.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(drag-drop): position reset if viewport is resized while boundary is invisible" (#17777)

Issues.Title: mat-select poorly handles "space" when performing typeahead
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

repro: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-hr8bq9

Steps to reproduce issue 1:
1. Focus on select with it closed
2. Type "United K"
3. When the space character is typed the select is opened

Steps to reproduce issue 2:
1. Open select
2. Type "United K"
3. When the space character is typed the select is closed and "United States" is selected
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
Space does not open/close the select when typeahead is being performed. " " character should be treated as part of the typeahead as long as the debounce time has not yet cleared.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
Space always opens the select when closed and always closes the select and selects an option when it is open.

#### Environment

- Angular:
- CDK/Material:
- Browser(s):
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-select poorly handles "space" when performing typeahead" (#17774)
